title: Girl, 7, has legs amputated after doctors mistake meningitis for tummy bug
text:
It is believed Brogan contracted meningitis while on holiday and fell very sick when she returned home (Picture: BPM)

A little girl had to have both of her legs amputated after contracting meningitis while on holiday and initially being told it was just a tummy bug.

Brogan-Lei Partridge, 7, was sent home from A&E by medics but hours later had to be readmitted and spent the next week in a coma.

Her mother, Amy Partridge, 28, is urging other parents to be more aware of the symptoms of the potentially deadly condition and said her daughter is struggling to regain her independence.

Brogan, from Rednal, Birmingham, lost both of her legs after contracting septicemia caused by Meningitis B.

Mum-of-four Amy said: ‘We’d just came back from a family break when she contracted meningitis.

‘She did not seem herself. She’d had a sleepless night and was vomiting. We took her to A&E but they sent us home, saying she only had a tummy bug.

‘I didn’t know the symptoms of meningitis at the time. But within about three hours of leaving A&E, she was rushed back in after she started getting a rash.

‘When we got back in the doctors then confirmed our worst fears.’

Brogan in hospital after being put into a coma while fighting meningitis (Picture: BPM)

The rash that quickly spread across Brogan’s legs (Picture: BPM)

Brogan was taken into intensive care and her parents were told it was a ‘life or death’ situation and that her feet would need to be amputated.

Amy said: ‘The damage was done within just a few hours.

‘When we first found out she was going to lose her legs, we thought there was absolutely no way that could happen.

‘I didn’t want my little girl to lose her legs but it was the only option.’

Four years on and brave Brogan, now 11, is working on rebuilding her life.

Amy said: ‘She’s always had a good mindset and is determined to get her full independence back.’

A recent study by pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline found more than half of parents had little or no knowledge that vaccines could help prevent some forms of meningitis.

While new data from Public Health England last month revealed the number of children being vaccinated across England has dropped.

Numbers dropped across all 13 routine vaccinations, including those for meningitis and the combined measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine.

Brogan, now 11, is working on rebuilding her lift after having her legs amputated (Picture: BPM)

Doctors have slammed ‘myths’ being spread by parents at school gates that vaccines are dangerous.

Advertisement

Advertisement

NHS England’s chief executive Simon Stevens warned against ‘toxic’ pseudoscience spread by so-called ‘anti-vaxxers’ after the World Health Organisation announced the UK is no longer measles-free.

Rob Dawson, Director of Support and Communications for Meningitis Research Foundation, said: ‘Meningitis acts quickly and is difficult to spot.

‘In the early stages in can be confused with flu but it can kill in less than 24 hours.

‘The consequences of bacterial meningitis can be devastating: 1 in 10 will die and many more are left with life-changing impairments, such as brain injury or amputations.

‘That’s why it is so vital for people to get their vaccines.’
